eviously noted, response actions are coordinated with the Shawnee Township Fire Department.  A Smart Plan/ERAP is in place to inform employees about what to do in case of a release and/or fire and subsequently implement emergency notification procedures. 

The Shawnee Township Fire Department has participated in initial butane process and response training.  Additionally, annual notification and coordination exercises are completed with local first responders per Marathon's drills/exercise program. 

E. PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY 

Marathon is continually striving to make the Lima LP Terminal the safest and most reliable workplace possible for its employees, neighbors and community. 

In an effort to improve and promote a process safety culture, employees complete multiple PSM and RMP related education opportunities along with establishing regular terminal representative meetings and maintaining consistent communication with its butane business partner.

scheduled safety inspections and audits; and 
-Frequent unit surveillance by operators. 

General Release Mitigation
 
-Automatic and remotely operated shut-offs to limit release quantities; 
-Strategically located valves to isolate leaks; and 
-Hydrocarbon detectors at key areas to warn of a release and initiate a process and terminal shutdown.

General Emergency Response 

-Emergency alert system; 
-Periodic emergency training for employees; 
-Communication systems with local emergency responders and regulatory agencies; 
-Emergency drills with Terminal personnel, regulatory agencies, and community emergency responders to enhance response skills and coordination among agencies; 
-Mutual Aid with local Fire Departments; and 
-Participation with the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) or its equivalent. 

Further, the Lima LP Terminal complies with the National Fire Protection Association's (NFPA's) Liquefied Petroleum Gas (LPG) Code (NFPA-58) requirements for LP Gas storage. In addition to the presence of appropriate controls to prevent and limit possible releases of butane, if a release does occur, a Smart Plan/Emergency Response Action Plan (ERAP) is in place for the Facility and response activities are coordinated with the Shawnee Township Fire Department and Allen County Hazardous Materials Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).
 
C. FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY 

The Lima LP Terminal has an excellent record of accident prevention. The terminal maintains records for all significant accidental chemical releases that occur at this facility inclusive of root-cause analyses and associated follow-up actions, as appropriate.  As this is a new process, there have been no accidents within the previous five (5) years resulting in consequences as defined within the EPA RMP reporting requirements.  The Terminal tracks all process incidents per API 754 guidance. 

D. EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM 

The Lima LP Terminal is identified as a Non-Responding Facility.  As pr

ertain safety precautions during handling to prevent unnecessary human exposure, reduce the threat to employee health, and 
minimize the threat and impact to nearby members of the community.  Safety at the Facility depends upon the manner in which butane is handled as well as the various safety systems incorporated into the design of the process. Furthermore, comprehensive training is provided to employees, which reinforces the safety policies and procedures of the Lima LP Terminal.
 
The facility has fixed inventories of butane. Butane is received by truck (transports) and stored in one (1) 60,000 gal. pressure vessel.  The butane is then pumped to a blending/injection skid for direct injection into blend grade and premium unleaded gasoline lines feeding the site gasoline truck-loading rack. Injection quantities are controlled via the blending skid, analyzer and PLC.  Process safety controls include internal/excess flow valves, fusible elements (<250 degrees Fahrenheit), emergency shut-off valves (fail safe), fill shutoff on the vessel, manual emergency shutoff devices (ESDs) throughout and on the video display terminal, line hydrostatic pressure reliefs, and component grounding.   Secondary to the primary rack blending is product tank batch blending which allows for the offload of butane directly into product tank recirculation stream during the summer season.  

Access to the Lima LP Terminal is restricted to employees, management personnel and authorized contractors/visitors. 

B. GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION MEASURES 

Marathon's accidental release prevention and emergency planning/response programs help effectively manage the hazards posed by the Terminal's regulated substances to its employees, the public, and the environment. The covered process is regulated by the EPA RMP regulation 40 CFR Part 68, as well as the OSHA Process Safety Management standard 29 CFR 1910.119.  Note that RMP enforcement has been del

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RELEASE POLICIES 

MPLX Terminals, LLC - Lima LP Terminal is a refined petroleum product distributor.  The Lima LP Terminal is an onshore, light products, bulk petroleum storage terminal used in the storage and distribution of petroleum products to retail and commercial end-users in the vicinity of Lima, OH. The Terminal handles and stores various grades of unleaded gasoline, 
low-sulfur diesel, fuel oil, butane, ethanol, and various other petroleum-based additives. 

The Lima LP Terminal is committed to operating and maintaining processes in a safe, reliable and environmentally sound manner. Marathon believes that excellent performance in health, safety, and the environment (HES) goes hand in hand with operating reliably, and that outstanding HES performance is of paramount importance. 

The Lima LP Terminal is designed, operated and maintained in a manner that protects the environment, as well as the health and safety of employees, contractors and the community. Marathon promotes health, safety, and the environment through programs of awareness, compliance, prevention and protection. These programs include a combination of accidental release prevention and emergency response planning. This document provides a brief overview of the comprehensive risk management activities that Marathon has developed and implemented, including: 

A. A description of the facility and the use of regulated substances; 
B. An overview of the accidental release prevention programs; 
C. A five-year accident history for accidental releases of regulated chemicals; 
D. An overview of the emergency response program; and 
E. An overview of planned changes to improve safety. 

A. STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES
